addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

26 May
1592
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
Ambassado
rs
from
e
Electo
r
Palatin
.

page.lettertext:
fol.50r
May it please yo
r
good L. Heere are cer-
taine Ambassado
rs
come newly to the Hage
from
e Elector Palatin, to witte
e
Baron
of Winningbergh
and his sonne, and one
Mons
r
Durant
a Frenche man and a secretary to
e
Electo
r
. They have already had accesse to
e
general states
: and their message contened
these principall pointes. A gratulation unto
them for
e good successe
at they have had, in
e
administration of their gouvernment. A
remonstrance of
e losses
at
e Electo
r
hath
sustened by
e death of
D. Cassimir
. The
maner of his comming, to take possession of his
contreis: wherein he pleadeth for him self,
at by an ancient privilege of all his pre-
decesso
rs
, he was out of his wardshippe at
18 yeres of age: although
at
Bulla aurea
doe appoint him a gardian till
e age of 25:
A declaration of
e troubles into w
ch
is he brought
by
e violent intrusion of
e
D. of Simeren
his grand Uncle. His complaint unto the
Empero
r
,
for redresse of those wronges.
The Empero
rs
refusal to shewe him any favo
r
.
The intercession of certaine Princes, to make
an appointment between him and his Uncle.
The doubt
at he conceaveth,
at their endevo
rs
will be frustrat. A specification of di-
vers inconveniences,
at are likely to ensue,
if he should be overboren by
e might of his
enemies: wherein not onely he himself and
the cause of religion w
t
e Princes of
Germany,
fol.50v
but
e state of these contreis, and
e
F
r
Kinges
affaires will be greatly prejudiced. Lastly
his intention to stand in defense of
e right of his
cause: whereto he made request, if his enemies
would oppresse him, to be assisted from hens w
t
men and mony. This is
e summe, as I am
informed, of all
at they proposed. And because
there can be no answear delivered heere unto
them, till every several Province hath conside-
red of
e mater, they doe therfor determine to
goe presently for
England,
and returning backe
againe, to take
e answear of
e states. For as
farre as I per ceave by their speeches unto me,
they are chiefly sent unto her
Ma
tie
to negotiat
in effect
e same as they doe heere: and to make
restitution of
e garter of D. Cassimir, and
of
e booke of statutes appertening to the or-
der. It is resolved by
e states,
upon
e instant intreatie of
e Captaines and
commaunders of their forces in France,
at they
shall be revoked. For it seemes
at they are
not 500 in number: w
ch
doe greatly complaine
of all maner of wantes: and
Count Philip
of
their fewenesse: for w
ch
he thinkes it no hono
r
,
to be there any longer. Howbeit it is per-
mitted to
e King, if his neede so require, to re-
tene a convenient number, to be placed in
garrison, in some good towne of
Normandie.
I can not yet signifie, what successe
we shall have, about
e enterprise of
steen-
wicke
. The 20 of this moneth they w
t
in
fol.51r
were content, to come to a Parley. But there
folowed no agreement. And whether they
meant but to sette a trappe, or to feele
e
humor of
Count Maurice
, or to gaine a litle
time, because they hope to be assisted, it is
diversly construed. For they stood very
stout, and would yelde to no conditions.
The self same day at night,
Verdugo
who
was at
Coevoerden
neere adjoining, sent
a convoy of 200 w
t
a quantitie of powder,
to enter
e towne. But being presently
discovered, there were slaine to
e number of
40 as many taken prisoners, and
e rest
put to flight. There is a bruite at
this p
nt
, that they are in Parley once againe.
But knowing nothing certaine, and ex-
pecting every houre for some advertisment
from thens, I leave yo
r
L. to my next,
and take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. June 26 1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
Before I closed my letter,
heere was newes from
e campe,
that Count Maurice was shotte
in one of his cheakes, but w
t
out
any danger: and
at fire being
put to divers of o
r
mines, it hath
made suche a breache, as there is
present hope, to enter
e towne.
